name: Milk Thistle
summary: Milk thistle (Silybum marianum) is an herbal supplement traditionally used for liver health. Its active compound, silymarin, has antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and hepatoprotective effects, and has been investigated for metabolic, psychiatric, and neurological benefits.
description: Milk thistle is a flowering plant whose seeds contain silymarin, a mixture of flavonolignans with antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties. It has a long history of use as a liver tonic and is commonly taken to support liver function in cases of alcohol-related liver disease, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), hepatitis, and toxin-induced liver injury. Emerging evidence suggests possible benefits for metabolic regulation, cognition, and psychiatric health, though research is less conclusive outside of hepatology. It is widely available as an over-the-counter herbal supplement.

metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved for liver disease)

contraindications: Allergy to ragweed or related plants (Asteraceae family)
Pregnancy and breastfeeding (safety not well established)
monitoring_required: Liver function tests (if used therapeutically for liver disease)

sections.text: Silymarin, the active component of milk thistle, stabilizes cell membranes, reduces lipid peroxidation, scavenges free radicals, and enhances antioxidant defenses. It also modulates inflammatory pathways and may promote liver regeneration.

adult.typical: 140–420 mg standardized silymarin extract daily (divided doses)

sections.pediatric: Not well established—use not generally recommended

sections.text: Onset: Gradual, over weeks to months. Duration: Benefits may persist with continued supplementation.

other: Not a substitute for medical treatment of liver disease.
May interact with medications metabolized by CYP2C9, CYP3A4, and P-gp.

items.action: Monitor lipid levels and adverse effects

items: Liver function tests in chronic users with liver disease

sections.pediatrics: Not established—avoid unless supervised by a clinician

sections.text: No tapering required; may be discontinued without withdrawal effects.

items: Evidence strongest for liver-related benefits, particularly in toxin- or alcohol-related injury.
Silymarin bioavailability varies by preparation; standardized extracts preferred.
Often used in integrative psychiatry as an adjunct due to antioxidant and neuroprotective potential.

items.label: Abenavoli L et al. Milk thistle in liver diseases. Phytother Res. 2010.

seo.description: Milk thistle (Silybum marianum) is an herbal supplement rich in silymarin, studied for liver support, antioxidant effects, and metabolic health benefits.
